newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila to drop illegal entry charge vs Chinese.
newsitem.headline: Manila to drop illegal entry charge vs Chinese.

text.p: A Philippine committee will recommend the withdrawal of illegal entry charges against 21 Chinese fishermen arrested off a disputed rocky outcrop in the South China Sea, a senior official said on Wednesday.

Foreign Affairs undersecretary Rodolfo Severino told reporters the national committee on illegal entrants would ask government prosecutors to withdraw the charges against the Chinese and instead file a case of illegal fishing.
"They (Chinese) were apparently outside Philippine territory," Severino said, adding the fishermen were only passing through the country's 200-mile exclusive economic zone.
Philippine police have filed charges of illegal entry against the Chinese after they were arrested on May 20 off Scarborough Shoal, a rock formation that Manila said was within its economic zone.
Beijing said the shoal and all other islets, reefs and rocks in the South China historically belong to China.
Under the United Nations Convention on Law of the Sea, foreign vessels can pass through a country's exclusive economic zone provided they do not exploit resources in the area, Severino said.
Severino said the Philippine Navy found tonnes of fish on the Chinese fishermen's boat.
China has protested to the Philippines over the incident, demanding the release of the fishermen.
The arrest of the Chinese fishermen was the third diplomatic row between Manila and Beijing over the outcrop last month.

China earlier protested against the hoisting by Filipinos of their national flag over the rocks. It protested again when a group of Philippine congressmen sailed to the shoal to be photographed standing under the flag.

The shoal lies north of the Spratly Islands, a cluster of potentially oil-rich isles, reefs and atolls that the two countries are also scrapping over. The Spratlys are also claimed wholly or in part by Vietnam, Taiwan, Brunei and Malaysia.
